title: Optimized protocols for efficient gene editing in mouse hepatocytes in vivo using CRISPR-Cas9 technology
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Production of AAV
Timing: 6 days
Preparation of HEK293T cells.
Seed HEK293T cells into a 10 cm dish. Cells were cultured in DMEM supplemented with penicillin-streptomycin and 10% FBS at 37°C in a 5% CO2 incubator.
When the cells reach 80% confluence, split cell to 5 10 cm dishes.
Pass 5 dishes of HEK293T cells to 25 dishes, when the cells reach 80% confluency.
Note: 25 dishes of HEK293T cells can pack 1013–1014 viruses. You can use the appropriate amount of 293T cells for virus packaging according to your needs.
Plasmids transfection.
When the cell density reaches 80%–90%, prepare for transfection.
Preheat PEI solution and DMEM at 37°C.
Add the pAAV2/8, pAdDeltaF6, and AAV-Cre-sgRNA to DMEM, pipetting up and down a few times to mix.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1319_10.csv
Add 90 μL PEI (the ratio of PEI volume (mL) to the amount of total DNA (mg) is 3:1) to the Plasmid/DMEM mixture.
Vortex the mixture. Place at 20°C–24°C for 10 min.
Gently add the mixture dropwise to the cell culture medium and shake gently to mix.
Note: The amount of reagent used in step 2 is for transfecting 1 dish of HEK293T cells.
Optional: The AAV-Cre-sgRNA plasmid can be replaced with the pAAV-GFP plasmid, and one dish of HEK293T cells can be transfected at the same time to test the transfection efficiency. 24 h after transfection, GFP-positive cells should be greater than 80%. Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]
After 10–12 h of plasmids transfection, replace the medium with fresh culture medium.
Harvest of AAV
Timing: 1–2 days
After 60 h of plasmid transfection, harvest the AAV from the culture medium and HEK293T cells.
Harvest the AAV from the culture medium.
Collect all the culture medium in several 50 mL centrifuge tubes.

Centrifuge at 3000 g for 10 min to remove cell debris.
Transfer all the supernatant to new centrifuge tubes.
Pipette 15 mL of supernatant into the centrifugal filter.
Centrifuge at 3000 g for 30 min at 4°C.
Remove the bottom fraction. Collect the concentrated supernatant in the filter into a new 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Repeat steps d-f, until all the supernatant is concentrated.
Critical: All supernatant should be concentrated to less than 7 mL, otherwise one centrifuge bottle will not be enough to hold all the concentrated supernatants.
Isolation of the AAV from HEK293T cells.
Add 1–2 mL DMEM into one dish and resuspend the HEK293T cells with a pipette by pipetting up and down several times.
Transfer the suspension to a 50 mL centrifuge tube.
In the same way, transfer the remaining 24 dishes of HEK293T cells to the 50 mL centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge at 3000 g for 15 min at 4°C
Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 3 mL lysis buffer.
Freeze the resuspended cells in an alcohol bath at −80°C for 30 min
Quickly transfer the frozen cells to a 37°C water bath for 20 min.
Repeat steps f to g.
Put the thawed cell suspension in the −80°C alcohol bath.
Purification of AAV
Timing: 1 day
Quickly transfer the frozen cells from step 5 to a 37°C water bath for 20 min.
Mix the concentrated supernatant from step 4 and the freeze-thaw cell suspension, add 1 M MgCl2 to a final MgCl2 concentration of 1 mM.
Add Benzonase to the mixture to a final Benzonase concentration of 25 U/mL, mix well and incubate at 37°C for 30 min.
Centrifuge at 3000 g for 20 min at 4°C.

Preparation of discontinuous iodixanol gradients (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). Slowly add 3.5 mL 60%, 3.5 mL 40%, 4 mL 25%, 4 mL 17% iodixanol to the centrifuge bottle from bottom to top.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1319-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Illustration of iodixanol gradients before centrifugation
The liquid in the centrifuge bottle from bottom to top is 60%, 40%, 25%, 17% iodixanol, and unpurified AAV.
Add the supernatant from step 9 onto the top of the 17% layer of iodixanol gradients very slowly and gently.
Use Beckman Optima XPN-100-IVD ultracentrifuge, 70Ti rotor – centrifugation at 60000 rpm (max rcf ≈ 370000 g) for 2 h at 4°C, acceleration 6, deceleration 9.
Using a 5 mL syringe and a 20-gauge needle to collect the 40% layer of iodixanol gradients.
Transfer the 40% iodixanol to a centrifugal filter.
Fill up the centrifugal filter with PBS. The volume after filling is about 15 mL.
After mixing upside down, centrifuge at 3000 g for 30 min at 4°C. Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]
Remove the bottom fraction.
Repeat step 15 to 17 twice.
Collect the remaining virus suspension in the filter into a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube, add PBS to dilute to about 1 mL. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]
After pipetting and mixing, aliquot 100 μL virus into each tube and freeze at −80°C. Aspirate 5 μL and prepare for AAV titer measurement later.
Pause point: Store at −80°C until titer measurement or AAV injection.
qPCR for AAV genome titer measurement
Timing: 4 h
Prepare standards. Dilute the AAV-Cre-sgRNA plasmid at a ratio of 1:10 into 7 gradients. The highest starting concentration is recommended to be around 10 μg/mL.
Preparation of viral genomic DNA
Incubate 5 μL virus with DNase I at 37°C for 10 min to remove residual DNA in the solution.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1319_11.csv
Incubate the mixture at 95°C for 10 min to denature DNase I

Add 1 μL proteinase K and incubate at 37°C for 10 min to digest the virus protein coat.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1319_12.csv
Inactivate proteinase K at 95°C for 10 min.
Set up the qPCR reactions.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1319_13.csv
Set up and run the real-time PCR instrument.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1319_14.csv
Calculate the titer of the virus
The number of copies N of single-stranded DNA per microliter in each standard can be approximated using the following formula from the concentration C (μg/μL) and the length L (bp) of the standard of the plasmid.
  N ≈ 2 ×   6.02 ×  10 23    2 × 330 × L   × C ×  10  − 6    
Note: The average relative molecular mass of each deoxyribonucleoside is approximately 330. The length of the plasmid standard is L. Therefore, the relative molecular mass of the standard product is 2 × 330 × L. 6.02 × 1023 is Avogadro constant. So, the copy number of 2 × 330 × L g standard plasmid is about 6.02 × 1023.
Calculate the number of copies of single-stranded DNA in each standard
The Ct value of each standard product as the independent variable x, and the logarithm of the copy number with base 10 as the dependent variable y, to fit the linear regression equation (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]
The Ct value of the viral genome is substituted into the linear regression equation, and the value y is calculated. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]
10 to the power of y is the number of copies of the viral genome.
Because the virus is diluted 20 times in step 22, the concentration of the virus stock solution needs to be multiplied by 20.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1319-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. An example of linear regression equation curve for standard products

The abscissa is the Ct value of the standard product. The ordinate is the logarithm of the standard DNA copy number with the base ten. The linear regression equation is y = −0.3076x + 11.242. The coefficient of determination (R2) is 0.9983.
Injection of AAV
Timing: 2 h
Remove the AAV from −80°C and dissolve it at 37°C.
Dilute the virus titer with sterile PBS to 1 × 109/μL.
Inject 250 μL of virus per mouse via tail vein injection.
Critical: When mice in the experimental group were injected with AAVs carrying sgRNA (AAV-sgRNA), the control group should be injected with the same titer of AAVs without sgRNA (AAV-control).
Efficiency detection
Timing: 5 days
In vivo bioluminescence imaging to detect whether the virus successfully infects the animal livers.
Note: The AAV-Cre-sgRNA vector contains the luciferase gene, so in vivo bioluminescence imaging can be used to detect whether the virus successfully infects liver cells and expresses the viral genes.
1–2 weeks after virus injection, the virus infection is detected by in vivo imaging.
Each mouse was injected intraperitoneally with a luciferin/body weight concentration of 150 mg/kg.
After 10–15 min, when the light signal reaches the strongest stable plateau, perform the imaging analysis.
Detect the green fluorescence of mouse liver tissue to determine whether the mouse successfully expresses the Cas9 protein.
Note: In the Rosa26-LSL-Cas9 animals, the EGFP protein is co-expressed with Cas9 via a P2A linker sequence. Therefore, by observing the green fluorescence of the mouse liver, we can judge whether expression of the Cas9 protein in liver cells is successfully induced.
Detect the green fluorescence of the whole liver.
The mice were anesthetized by intraperitoneal injection of 4% chloral hydrate at a dose of 10 mL/kg.
Open the abdominal cavity of the mouse and remove the liver.

The liver was washed to remove residual blood in PBS.
Put the liver in a 6 cm culture dish.
Observe the green fluorescence of the liver with a fluorescence microscope.
Detect the green fluorescence of frozen sections of the liver.
Cut the liver tissue block with a thickness of less than 5 mm.
Place the tissue block onto a cryomold.
Cover the entire tissue block with the OCT compound.
Slowly put the bottom of the mold into liquid nitrogen until the entire tissue block is completely frozen.
Transfer the frozen tissue block to a cryotome cryostat. Cut sections at a thickness of 4 μm.
Observe the green fluorescence of liver slices with a fluorescence microscope.
Use T7E1 assay to detect genome editing efficiency.
Design primers to amplify mouse genome sites targeted by the sgRNA.
Note: We recommend that the length of the PCR product should be between 600 bp–1000 bp. Long PCR products will increase the difficulty of amplification. The distance from the cut site should be greater than 150 bp. Otherwise, it will be difficult to separate the undigested DNA band and the longer digested fragment through DNA gel, and the shorter digested fragment will also be blurry on the DNA gel.
Extract genomic DNA from mouse liver.
Use the primers to amplify the genomic sequence targeted by sgRNA.
Run the PCR products on a 1% agarose gel. Cut the target DNA band and extract the DNA using a gel extraction kit.
Denature the DNA at 95°C for 5 min, then slowly cool the solution 0.1°C/s to 25°C in a thermocycler.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1319_15.csv
Digest the annealed DNA fragments with 0.5 μL T7 Endonuclease I (T7EI) enzyme at 37°C for 30 min.
Run samples on a 1% agarose gel.

Determine the cleavage efficiency by quantifying gel bands without overexposing them. A high-efficiency sgRNA will result in obvious cleavage bands, whereas the negative controls should have no cleavage band.
Use Western blot to detect whether the target protein in mouse liver has been successfully knocked out.
